subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: More stuff on Clearscript
msgSnippet: Chuck: I think you ve hit on a valid point.  I have read posts by people who seem to think there is a problem with QS s design because they find it tough going
messageBody:
Chuck:

I think you've hit on a valid point. I have read posts by people who seem to think there is a problem with QS's design because they find it tough
going to build up their reading speed. I think they are failing to take into account how much time they have spent in their life reading TO. Even
when we don't intend to read, we are surrounded constantly by advertising and end up reading it.

If we want to gain reading speed in QS, we have to read QS a lot. Your method of rereading several day's journal entries sounds excellent to me. Of
course it would be even better to read other people's QS. Is there anyone here on the list that could help up us set up a place to write back and
forth in QS?

Paige Gabhart

Chuck Peck wrote:

> I?ve used Quickscript for quite a while now. I both
> read and write it without any aid of charts or
> cheat-sheets. I Love languages and speak several. With
> that behind us, discussions about alphabets can be
> helpful here.
>
> When you talk about ?voiced?, un-voiced?, ?IPA
> distinctions? but most children would give you a blank
> look if you starting into a discussion on them. I
> believe that and effective language should be simple
> enough that a child can learn it. One way to help
> someone to learn a language is to have the most used
> characters as simple as possible. So once you learn
> most used characters, you?d be able to write a lot of
> stuff.
>
> Language is as much about reading as its? about
> writing, so an alphabet should address the reader as
> much as the writer. When we read effectively, we read
> whole word forms, not letter by letter. So languages
> that contain all parallel forms can be hard to read
> fast. You?re forced to interpret each letter. I think
> the use of descending and raised characters should be
> used sparingly and only as part of forming whole word
> distinction.
>
> I agree that related sounds should have a like or
> inverse lettering scheme aid in memorization.
>
> You said, ?In the case of quickscript, for instance, I
> believe it is imbalanced slightly on the side writing
> speed against mnemonics and readability.? LOL No
> flack, we all have our views. I think that unless a
> person is using an alphabet a LOT, even if they can
> write it, they still might not be able to write it in
> a speedy manner. It takes a lot of reading to get used
> to the word shapes/ionized forms. I journal most every
> day and all my daily personal writings are in
> Quickscript. Every time I go to journal, I go back and
> read several days worth of old writings. It?s taken a
> long time but I read Quickscript just about as fast as
> standard English character writing.
>
> Thanks for you comments!
> Chuck
>
> --- kyudosha <kyudosha@...> wrote:
> > I know this may be getting annoying, but I'm a bit
> > of an alphabet-
> > phile, so I'm sure you'll all bear with me. I also
> > know that this is
> > a forum for the read alphabet, so I'll be keeping my
> > clearscript
> > correspondance to email from here on out, but there
> > are some general
> > things that I wanted to bring to light here.
> >
> > ------
> >
> > I still think the vowels should be moved to the
> > writing line. This
> > way, they are actually sharply differentiated
> > against the rest of the
> > letters by their height. Perhaps they could all be
> > moved to the
> > upper parallel to make them sort of floaty (as
> > vowels tend to be),
> > but I'll leave that to you.
> >
> > Also, the voiced characters as descenders are going
> > to make for some
> > very messy writing & I will explain why:
> >
> > In english, you will note that we have very few
> > descending letters:
> > lowercase g,j,p,q,and y only. These are because
> > descenders tend to
> > clutter, clump and generally make unreadable
> > whatever is directly
> > below them. You will also note that, in response to
> > this, the
> > descenders we DO have are comparatively simple and
> > uncluttered; they
> > are straight and thin or slightly curved and thin.
> > In your scheme,
> > you will have large portions of characters resting
> > below the writing
> > line, and this will virtually necessitate a
> > double-spaced and
> > inefficient format. Other languages have solved
> > (or never
> > encountered) the problem of descenders by simply
> > making one square
> > writing line (Chinese, Japanese, Korean for
> > instance). I would
> > suggest the same to you. Once again, I would argue
> > that most people
> > do not really make the IPA distinctions (in this
> > case between voiced
> > and unvoiced). HowEVER, people ARE able to think of
> > a relation
> > between sounds, so your scheme of inversing letters
> > to denote
> > voiced/unvoiced pairs is still a good one and will
> > help in
> > memorization.
> >
> > If you still wish to retain some immediately
> > definining character
> > between voiced and unvoiced, perhaps a little
> > tweaking is in order?
> > Maybe make all unvoiced characters start in the
> > lower right quadrant
> > and all voiced ones in the upper right? Those
> > exceptions to pairs
> > could start anywhere else. These are of course just
> > random ideas to
> > let you know directions you could take.
> >
> > I personally think it would be fine without such
> > distinctions aside
> > from the inverting. When creating a new alphabet,
> > it is often easy
> > to err on the side of either mnemonics, readability
> > or writing speed,
> > whilst throwing one or both of the others out of
> > balance. In the
> > case of quickscript, for instance, I believe it is
> > imbalanced
> > slightly on the side writing speed against mnemonics
> > and
> > readability. Now, I know I'll probably catch some
> > flak for saying
> > that here, but it's true. This is not to say that
> > Quickscript needs
> > to be changed. Far from it. In fact, I still love
> > it. I'm just
> > pointing out some things for perspective. English
> > as-is is
> > unbalanced against mnemonics, and clearscript (even
> > without
> > descenders) has one-up in this instance.
> >
> > In making a usable alphabet, it's all about what's
> > important to you
> > and about considering who you're creating for. Keep
> > in mind that
> > most alphabet learning is done by straight
> > memorization anyway and
> > has been for millenia. As well, if you are to
> > replace Traditional
> > Orthography, you're going to need to provide a lot
> > of advantage with
> > little or no disadvantage in these three categories.
> > Further
> > difficulty arises in getting someone to use your
> > alphabet when they
> > already have a native one.
> >
> > Sound tough?
> >
> > It IS.
> >
> > Good luck. I'll be around for any input or bitching
> > you may want.
> >
> >
>
